messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: please klick.......... _http://www.esnips.com/web/menuki_ (http://www.esnips.com/web/menuki) this is from a restoration project by Dr. Lewitte ( spelling ?
messages.messageBody:
please klick..........

_http://www.esnips.com/web/menuki_ (http://www.esnips.com/web/menuki)

this is from a restoration project by Dr. Lewitte ( spelling ? )for a
massive naginata naoshi papered to Hoju ( early Muromachi ) by the NBTHK.
The tsuka has gold brocade ( instead of same ).
Dr. Lewitte has the brocade and the saya cleaned up in Japan, purchased a
signed shoami katana size tsuba, big Hizen style f/k and this Ezo menuki to
complete the restoration.

The Ezo menuki is 7 cm. in length.

Above info are from private correspondence between the good Doctor and a
good friend of mine who passed the deal to me..................

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: It was my impression that menuki assigned to Ezo were not only made with a thin plate but also they had a unique method of -- and I m not sure of the correct
messages.messageBody:
It was my impression that menuki assigned to Ezo were not only made with a thin plate but also they had a unique method of -- and I'm not sure of the correct terminology here -- gilding on them, something similar to found in Chinese artworks. A year or so ago I wrote an article for the JSS/US to illustrate some menuki depicting the mythical "baku." The one set of menuki were fairly large sized as one might expect in Ezo but the other set were what I'd call "normal" menuki size, but they also had all the other characteristics of Ezo. To me, it seemed somewhat unusual to find the "baku" creature depicted on menuki thought to be Ezo. Earlier, I did show these to both Jim Gilbert and Bob Haynes and they agreed that they appeared to be Ezo works. But really, I wonder who knows; Buttweiler's writings on Ezo are about all I've ever really found regarding Ezo, at least what comes to mind tonight.

Here now is a nice Echizen Kanenori katana that was found in nice quality WWII gunto mounting. What's kind of unique is that the tsuka has menuki depicting a fairly large "tiger" which -- judging while held in place under wrapping -- really does have the look of possibly being Ezo. The "worn gold gilding" is there, the size is right, but I wonder. I'd love to remove these but find it difficult to bring myself to unwrap this tsuka in order to "get them into my hand." (The wrap is already broken, but remains almost all there and intact.) Now I would think it unusual, as with the "baku," to find Ezo menuki depicting a running "tiger." It is a temptation to have a look at these, for sure! If these are no Ezo, I wonder where they should be placed?

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Alan Bale
To: Study Group
Sent: Monday, December 11, 2006 6:25 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki


I don't think there is any real connection between Ezo and Ko-Mino menuki, Ezo menuki are generally larger and with a less detailed design (large cherry blossom etc), I wonder if those smaller Ezo menuki with a detailed design are Ezo at all.

Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, December 10, 2006 5:23 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki

http://page10.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/jp/auction/m35952378

Can anyone elaborate on where these fit in historically? From my
understanding of early menuki from Buttweiler the Ezo (aka: Shoki
Kinko) developed into the Ko Mino but I am wondering if the Ezo
continued along side the Mino group. These are very sophisticated in
construction but have the typical patina of the Ezo although in much
better condition than usually seen.
Thanks much!

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pete, The kanji for the maker is not clear enough but they are made of yamagane and are Nanbokucho period. Alan ... From: klepet33319 To:
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pete,
The kanji for the maker is not clear enough but they are made of yamagane and are Nanbokucho period.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, December 11, 2006 1:04 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Aizu / Shoki Kinko Menuki


Hi Alan -- I know where you are coming from about the design.
Buttweiler had theorized there was a connection based upon
construction techniques I believe. I am having trouble making out
the attribution on the juyo papers but I believe it is to Ezo.
Perhaps Jim &/or Gordon can jump in on this?
